newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times front page - Jan 31.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times front page - Jan 31.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following stories on its front page Friday:

-- The National Governors' Association has decided to oppose President Clinton's plan to set firm limits on federal Medicaid spending, arguing that the plan would put a heavier burden on the states for providing the poor with health care.

-- Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan urged Congress to limit cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefits and revived his call for the creation of an independent commission to set more accurate increases for inflation.

-- New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's preliminary budget calls for spending $500 million to ease overcrowding in public schools and $550 million in spending cuts at city agencies, including a $155 million reduction for the municipal hospital agency.

-- Justice Department investigators have uncovered numerous complaints by employees at the Federal Bureau of Investigation's crime laboratory about the way their superiors handled evidence in the Oklahoma City bombing.

-- A plan to rescue the savings and loan industry and proposed banking legislation were among the topics discussed in a coffee meeting last May between bank industry officials, Clinton and the country's top bank regulator.
-- An assistant commissioner at the Internal Revenue Service acknowledged that his agency spent $4 billion on its computer systems but that the systems do not function well.
-- India's citizens scatter some of the ashes of Mohandas Gandhi to commemorate the January 30, 1948, assassination of one of the founding fathers of Indian independance.
